choices.text: Total hyphema within 1 hour

questions.text: A 17-year-old female with no previous medical history, was brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. During evaluation, hyphema in the left eye was detected. Which of the following conditions does not require surgical intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total hyphema within 1 hour

 

Option D:

 

A total hyphema, where the entire anterior chamber is filled with blood, can be alarming but does not necessarily require immediate surgical intervention. The initial management is conservative, including bed rest, head elevation, and eye protection. Surgical intervention is considered if complications arise, such as persistently elevated IOP or corneal staining.

 

Hyphemas can be graded in the following manner:

 

 

 

The patient can typically be monitored for the first 4 days with medical treatment alone to allow for spontaneous resolution.  After that point, surgical intervention may be indicated in the setting of uncontrolled glaucoma, corneal blood staining, the persistence of a large or total hyphema, and active bleeding in the anterior chamber. 

 

  • Uncontrolled intraocular hypertension: > or = to 50 25mmhg for >5 days, or >25 50 mmHg for >24 hours.
  • If a large hyphema results in complete visual obstruction in a pediatric patient, amblyopia could result.

 

Indications for Surgical Intervention in Traumatic Hyphema: (table adapted from American Academy of Ophthalmology 2020–2021 BCSC Basic and Clinical Science Course™/8 External Disease and Cornea/Chapter 14: Clinical Aspects of Toxic and Traumatic Injuries of the Anterior Segment

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IOP ≥ 25 mmHg for > 5 Days: Elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) is a significant concern in hyphema. Persistent elevation (IOP ≥ 25 mmHg for more than 5 days) despite medical therapy (like topical beta-blockers, alpha agonists, and systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors) may indicate the need for surgical intervention. This is to prevent optic nerve damage and other complications associated with prolonged elevated IOP.

 

Option B. Corneal Blood Staining: This occurs when red blood cells and hemoglobin infiltrate the corneal stroma. It is a severe complication of hyphema, especially in the setting of high IOP. Corneal blood staining is more likely when there is total hyphema or repeated bleeding. Surgical intervention is often recommended to prevent permanent visual impairment due to corneal opacity.

 

Option C. IOP > 50 mmHg for >24 Hours: This is a critical condition. An IOP greater than 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours is a medical emergency due to the risk of optic nerve damage and other complications, such as corneal blood staining. Immediate surgical intervention is typically required to reduce the pressure and prevent irreversible damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of hyphema following trauma, surgical intervention is typically indicated for IOP ≥ 25 mmHg lasting more than 5 days, corneal blood staining, and IOP > 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours. However, total hyphema within 1 hour of injury usually does not require immediate surgical intervention unless complications develop.

 

Ref: American association of ophthalmology.  Https://eyewiki.aao.org/hyphema

2. https://www.aao.org/education/bcscsnippetdetail.aspx?id=31b9e6a0-5abe-4f7c-b457-ceafadddab3d

choices.text: Infraorbital nerve anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of a blow-out fracture of orbit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

 

Option A:

 

A blow out fracture of the orbital floor is caused by sudden increase in orbital pressure due to trauma.

 

Signs:

 

  • Enophthalmos - due to displacement of intraorbital contents
  • Diplopia – due to extra ocular muscle entrapment in fracture
  • Infra orbital anesthesia - if fracture involves infra orbital canal through which infra orbital nerve passes.
  • Others - periorbital edema, ecchymosis, subcutaneous emphysema, etc

 

PlainX-Ray- Water’s view is the best.

 

Most common wall of the orbit to be fractured in blow-out fractures is the floor.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Diplopia: It is a common symptom of blow-out fractures, often resulting from impaired movement of the affected eye due to muscle entrapment or nerve damage.

 

Option C. Enophthalmos: This is the posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. It is a characteristic sign of blow-out fractures. The increase in the orbital volume caused by the fracture allows the eyeball to sink backward.

 

Option D. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia: This refers to a loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve, typically the lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip. It can occur in blow-out fractures if the fracture involves the infraorbital groove or canal, where the nerve runs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enophthalmos, not exophthalmos, is a sign of blow-out fracture of the orbit. Blow-out fractures typically increase orbital volume, allowing the eyeball to sink backward, leading to enophthalmos, rather than protruding forward as in exophthalmos.

 

Ref: pg 864 kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of intermittent tearing from her left eye. Examination reveals no significant eye redness or visual impairment. She mentions the symptoms are more pronounced in windy conditions or when she is tired. Further examination of the eyelid function reveals a slight delay in tear drainage. Which part of the orbicularis oculi muscle, involved in tear drainage and commonly affected in such cases, is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lacrimal (Horner’s muscle)

 

Option B:

 

  • Orbicularis oculi fibres in the pre tarsal portion arising from the lacrimal fascia & upper part of lacrimal crest.
  • Helps in the drainage of tears.
  • Known as PARS LACRIMALIS.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Orbital Part: This part of the orbicularis oculi muscle is involved in the forceful closure of the eyelids, as in blinking. It's not directly involved in tear drainage.

 

Option B. Temporal Part: This is not a distinct part of the orbicularis oculi muscle; rather, the muscle has palpebral and orbital parts. The temporal part does not relate to tear drainage.

 

Option D. Muller’s Muscle: Muller's muscle, or the superior tarsal muscle, is a smooth muscle that contributes to eyelid elevation. It is not a part of the orbicularis oculi muscle and does not influence tear drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horner’s muscle refers to the lacrimal part of the orbicularis oculi muscle, which is integral in tear drainage.

 

Ref: pg 492/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muller’s muscle

 

Option D:

 

MULLER’S  Muscle:

 

  • It is a non-striated muscle of the eyelid.

  • ORIGIN: from inferior striated fibres of levator palpebrae superioris.

  • INSERTION: Orbital margin of tarsal plate.

  • NERVE SUPPLY: sympathetic nerve supply.

  • FUNCTION: Maintains elevation of eyelid.                               

  • Involvement of the Sympathetic chain of head and neck leads to HORNER’S SYNDROME characterised by a triad of ptosis, miosis and anhidrosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior Rectus: This muscle, responsible for elevating the eye, is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III), not by sympathetic nerves.

 

Option B. Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS): The LPS raises the upper eyelid and is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve. It is not supplied by sympathetic nerves.

 

Optiion C. Medial Rectus: This muscle, which moves the eye medially (towards the nose), is innervated by the oculomotor nerve as well. It does not receive sympathetic innervation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is Müller’s Muscle, a smooth muscle in the upper eyelid that aids in eyelid elevation.

 

Ref: pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which is the thickest wall of the orbit?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral wall

 

Option B:

 

  • Lateral orbital wall is made up of- zygomatic bone, greater wing of sphenoid.

  • It is the thickest & strongest orbital wall.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Medial Wall: The medial wall of the orbit is one of the thinnest and most fragile parts. It is formed primarily by the ethmoid bone and partly by the lacrimal bone, the frontal bone, and the lesser wing of the sphenoid. This wall separates the orbital cavity from the ethmoid air cells, making it prone to injury and subsequent communication with the nasal cavity.

 

 

Option C. Roof: The roof of the orbit is formed primarily by the orbital plate of the frontal bone and, to a lesser extent, by the lesser wing of the sphenoid. It separates the orbital contents from the anterior cranial fossa and provides protection from superior impacts. It's relatively thin compared to the lateral wall but stronger than the medial wall.

 

 

Option D. Floor: The floor of the orbit is formed by the orbital surface of the maxillary bone, along with small contributions from the zygomatic bone and the palatine bone. This wall is thin and vulnerable to fractures, especially from trauma to the orbit, as it separates the orbital contents from the maxillary sinus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral wall is the thickest wall of the orbit, providing substantial protection to the eye from lateral impacts, and distinguishing itself in strength and thickness from the more fragile medial wall, the moderately strong roof, and the thin, vulnerable floor of the orbit.

 

Ref: pg 578/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What is the volume of the vitreous?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 ml

 

Educational Objective:

 

The volume of the vitreous is = 4 ml.

 

Ref: pg 152/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: How much What is the volume of orbital cavity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30 ml

 

Educational Objective:

 

The volume of the orbital cavity is 29-30 ml.

 

Ref: anatomy & physiology of eye 3rd edition – Ak Khurana (pg 575)

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by his parents who are concerned about his unusual eyelid movement. They report that every time he suckles while breastfeeding, his right upper eyelid retracts unusually. There is no history of trauma or surgery. On examination, you notice that the right upper eyelid droops slightly in a neutral facial expression and elevates when the infant is smiling or crying. This condition is likely due to an aberrant connection between the muscles innervated by which two cranial nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 & 5

 

Option C:

 

  • Other names of Marcus-Gunn aJaw Winking Syndrome include Marcus-Gunn jaw winking phenomenon (MGP), Marcus Gunn ptosis, Marcus Gunn jaw winking trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis, Maxillopalpebral synkinesis, and Pterygoid-levator synkinesis.
  • These individuals have variable degrees of blepharoptosis in the resting, primary position.
  • It is one of the congenital cranial dysinnervation disorders.
  • It is associated with synkinetic movements of the upper eyelid during masticating movements of the jaw. It is usually unilateral but may present bilaterally also.
  • There occurs a coordinated synkinetic movement of the upper eyelid and the jaw as a result of an abnormal connection between the motor branches of the trigeminal nerve and superior division of oculomotor nerve.
  • The jaw-wink reflex consists of a momentary retraction/elevation of the upper eyelid (which was ptotic) upon stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscle, which is followed by a rapid return to a lower position.
  • The magnitude of the wink is worse in downgaze.
  • This synkinetic phenomenon may be elicited not only by opening the mouth, but also by thrusting the jaw to the contralateral side, jaw protrusion, chewing, smiling, or sucking.
  • Congenital synkinetic ptosis is also known as Marcus gunn jaw winking syndrome.
  • Synkinesis is when two or more muscles that are independently innervated have either simultaneous or coordinated movements.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 3 & 7: This option suggests a connection between the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which innervates the levator palpebrae superioris (responsible for eyelid elevation), and the facial nerve (CN VII), which controls facial expressions.

 

Option B.  4 & 5: The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, and the trigeminal nerve (CN V) is responsible for facial sensation and mastication. An aberrant connection here is unlikely to cause the described eyelid phenomenon.

 

Option D. 5 & 7: This option suggests a connection between the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and the facial nerve (CN VII). While the facial nerve is involved in facial expressions, the trigeminal nerve's role in sensation and mastication does not typically lead to eyelid synkinesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students preparing for residency, it's essential to understand that congenital synkinetic ptosis typically results from an aberrant innervation between the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and the motor division of Trigeminal nerve (CN V), leading to an unusual elevation of the eyelid during facial movements like smiling or crying.

 

Ref: pg 41, eyelids -kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition.

2. Demirci H, Frueh BR, Nelson CC. Marcus Gunn jaw-winking synkinesis: clinical features and management. Ophthalmology. 2010 Jul;117(7):1447-52. doi: 10.1016/j.ophtha.2009.11.014. Epub 2010 Feb 25. PMID: 20188419.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient came with the complaint of shortness of breath. On examination, fullness in the right supraclavicular region is observed. On ocular examination, right pupil is constricted. Which of the following is not a feature of the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterochromia Iridis

 

Option C:

 

This condition, characterized by a difference in color between the two irises, is not typically a feature of adult-onset Horner's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with congenital Horner's syndrome, where the condition is present from birth or early childhood.

 

Causes of HORNER’S SYNDROME:

 

  • Ptosis

  • Miosis

  • Heterochromia iridis

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ptosis: This is a hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome. It occurs due to paralysis of the Müller's muscle, a sympathetically innervated muscle in the eyelid, leading to a slight drooping of the upper eyelid.

 

Option B. Anhidrosis: This refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face. It is a feature of Horner's syndrome due to the disruption of sympathetic nerves that innervate sweat glands.

 

Option D. Enophthalmos: This refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. While mild enophthalmos can be associated with Horner's syndrome due to the lack of sympathetic tone to the orbitalis muscle, it is not as prominent or diagnostic as the other features.

 

Conclusion:

 

Heterochromia iridis is not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos being a less prominent associated feature.

 

Ref: pg344/anatomy & physiology of eye 3rd edition – ak Khurana (pg 575)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with an alleged history of assault was reported at the department of oral and maxillofacial surgery with orbital ecchymosis, periorbital oedema, subconjunctival haemorrhage and tenderness in the infraorbital region. Limitation of which of the following extra ocular movement occurs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevation

 

Option C:

 

  • The given CT scan shows tear drop sign of orbital floor fracture.
  • This fracture may be associated with entrapment of inferior rectus muscle which leads to restriction in elevation.
  • The forced duction test will be positive in a case of true restriction due to entrapment of inferior rectus.
  • The elevation, controlled by the superior rectus muscle, can be hindered in orbital floor fractures due to the entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle. This entrapment can create resistance against the superior rectus muscle, making it difficult for the patient to look upward. This is a classic sign of an orbital floor fracture.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Depression (Inferior Rectus Muscle): Normally, the inferior rectus muscle facilitates the depression of the eyeball (looking downward). In orbital floor fractures, the inferior rectus muscle can be entrapped or edematous, leading to restricted movement. However, this typically results in difficulty with elevation due to inhibited action against the superior rectus muscle, rather than depression itself.

 

Option B. Intorsion (Superior Oblique Muscle): Intorsion, or inward rotation of the eyeball, is controlled by the superior oblique muscle. Orbital floor fractures usually do not impact the trochlear nerve or the superior oblique muscle, so intorsion is generally unaffected.

 

Option D. Abduction (Lateral Rectus Muscle): Abduction, the movement of the eyeball outward, away from the nose, is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle. This movement is typically not affected in orbital floor fractures as the lateral rectus muscle and its nerve supply (abducens nerve) are not involved in the trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of an orbital floor fracture, the most commonly affected extraocular movement is elevation, primarily due to the entrapment or impairment of the inferior rectus muscle, which creates resistance against the superior rectus muscle responsible for elevating the eye.

 

Ref: pg 423/ orbit/ 6th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

choices.text: Anterior chamber

questions.text: The position of an intraocular foreign body is estimated from its relationship with the metallic ring placed at which part of the eye?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limbus

 

Option B:

 

The limbus is the junction between the cornea and the sclera.

 

It is a key landmark for localizing IOFBs, especially in radiographic imaging, because it provides a circumferential reference that aligns with the plane of the iris, allowing for precise localization of the IOFB in three-dimensional space.

 

Limbal ring method:

 

  • A metallic ring of corneal diameter is stitched at limbus & x-rays are taken.
  • One exposure is taken at anteroposterior view and 3 in lateral view.
  • The position of intraocular foreign body is estimated from its relation with the metallic ring in different positions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior Chamber: This is the fluid-filled space between the cornea and the iris. While foreign bodies can be present here, the anterior chamber is not typically used as a reference point for localizing IOFBs, as it doesn't provide a comprehensive reference for the entire eye.

 

Option C. Cornea: The cornea is the transparent front part of the eye that covers the iris and pupil. While it is critical in the examination of the eye, it is not typically used as a reference for localizing IOFBs, as its curvature and clarity can complicate precise localization.

 

Option D. Vitreous: The vitreous is a clear gel that fills the space between the lens and the retina. Although IOFBs can be located in the vitreous, using it as a reference point is challenging due to its transparency and the lack of anatomical landmarks within it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When localizing an intraocular foreign body, the limbus, the junction between the cornea and the sclera, serves as the primary reference point due to its circumferential nature and alignment with key eye structures, aiding in precise three-dimensional localization of the foreign body.

 

Ref: pg 435/ ocular injuries/ comprehensive ophthalmology 6th edition ak khurana

choices.text: Ice pack test
Snap back test

questions.text: In a 35-year-old woman with a history of right eye ptosis for 6 months, the eyelids appear asymmetrical, and the ptosis fluctuates throughout the day, worsening in the evening. The fatigability test shows positive results. Which of the following tests is not helpful in diagnosing the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Snap back test

 

Option C:

 

Snap back test is used for ectropion, to check lower lid laxity.

 

The following signs and symptoms given in the question are suggestive of Myasthenic ptosis:

 

  • Unilateral
  • Asymmetrical
  • Diurnal variation
  • Fatigability present

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Edrophonium Test: This test is useful in diagnosing MG. Edrophonium, a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to an improvement in muscle strength in patients with MG.

 

Option B. Ice Pack Test: This test is also helpful in MG. Cooling improves neuromuscular transmission, and thus, application of an ice pack on the eyelids can temporarily improve ptosis in MG.

 

Option D. Electromyography (EMG): EMG, especially single-fiber EMG, is a key diagnostic tool in MG. It measures the electrical activity of muscles and can detect the characteristic patterns of neuromuscular transmission failure seen in MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the evaluation of a patient with fluctuating ptosis and positive fatigability, suggesting Myasthenia Gravis, the Snap Back Test is not useful as it assesses eyelid laxity rather than neuromuscular strength or transmission, which are the key pathological features in Myasthenia Gravis.

 

Ref: pg 838/ neuro ophthalmology/ kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition

questions.text: Superior orbital fissure syndrome involves cranial nerves except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2

 

Option A:

 

Contents of superior orbital fissure:

 

 

Orbital apex syndrome: Superior orbital fissure contents+ CN 2 (Optic nerve)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic Nerve is not a content of the superior orbital fissure.

 

Ref: eyewiki.aao.org/orbital_apex_syndrome

choices.text: Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS)

questions.text: The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muller’s muscle

 

Option D:

 

MULLER’S MUSCLE: Smooth muscle in eyelid.

 

  • ORIGIN: Inferior striated fibres of LPS.
  • INSERTION: Orbital margin of tarsal plate.
  • NERVE SUPPLY: Sympathetic.
  • FUNCTION: Maintains elevation of eyelid.         

 

 

Involvement of the Sympathetic chain of head and neck leads to HORNER’S SYNDROME characterised by a triad of ptosis, miosis and anhidrosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior Rectus: Innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III).

 

Option B. Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS): Also innervated by the oculomotor nerve, this muscle primarily elevates the upper eyelid.

 

Option C. Medial Rectus: Innervated by the oculomotor nerve, this muscle controls the movement of the eye towards the nose (adduction).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muller’s muscle is innervated by sympathetic nervous system.

 

Ref: pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The contents of the superior orbital fissure are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CN  2

 

Option A:

 

Below is a schematic diagram showing the contents of Superior orbital fissure:

 

  • Optic nerve is not a content of superior orbital fissure. It passes through optic canal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CN2 does not pass through the superior orbital fissure.

 

Ref: pg 580/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Optic nerve & Oculomotor nerve
Optic nerve & Abducent nerve
Optic nerve & Ophthalmic artery
Optic nerve & Central retinal artery

questions.text: The optic canal contains?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Optic nerve & Ophthalmic artery

 

Option C:

 

OPTIC CANAL contains:

 

  1. Optic nerve
  2. Ophthalmic artery

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Optic nerve & Oculomotor nerve – CN 3 passes through the superior orbital fissure.

 

Option B. Optic Nerve and Abducent Nerve – CN 6 passes through the superior orbital fissure.

 

Option D. Optic Nerve and Central Retinal Artery – The Central Retinal Artery originates from the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery. The ophthalmic artery enters the orbit through the optic canal along with the optic nerve. The central retinal artery, a critical vessel for the retina, branches off from the ophthalmic artery and enters the optic nerve approximately 8-15 mm behind the globe (eyeball). It then runs within the optic nerve before emerging on the optic disc in the eye to supply the inner layers of the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The contents of the optic canal are the optic nerve and the ophthalmic artery.

 

Ref: pg 580/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Orbital branch of pterygopalatine ganglion
Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: The following structures pass through the infra orbital fissure, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Facial Nerve

 

Option D:

 

 

Mnemonic: “GEMIZI”

 

Contents of inferior orbital fissure:

 

G: Ganglionic branch from pterygopalatine ganglion to maxillary nerve

 

E: Emissary vein

 

M: Maxillary nerve (Vb)

 

I: Infraorbital Nerve(Vb), Infraorbital artery and vein

 

Z: Zygomatic Nerve (Vb)

 

I: Inferior ophthalmic vein

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Infraorbital Nerve: This nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2), indeed passes through the infraorbital fissure to enter the orbit and then continues to the face through the infraorbital canal.

 

Option B. Orbital Branch of the Pterygopalatine Ganglion: This is correct; the orbital branches of the pterygopalatine ganglion pass through the infraorbital fissure to supply the orbit.

 

Option C. Inferior Ophthalmic Vein: The inferior ophthalmic vein, which drains blood from the orbit, also passes through the infraorbital fissure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of orbital anatomy, the facial nerve does not pass through the infraorbital fissure.

 

Ref: pg 581/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Levator palpebrae superioris

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient who visited the OPD with difficulty in opening his left eye and complaints of double-vision in the same eye, has been diagnosed with left oculomotor nerve palsy. Which of the extraocular muscle will be spared?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior oblique

 

Option A:

 

  • Superior oblique muscle is supplied by Trochlear Nerve; rest of the given muscles are all supplied by Oculomotor nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Inferior Rectus: The inferior rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III). This nerve innervates most of the extraocular muscles, except for the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles.

 

Option C. Levator Palpebrae Superioris: This muscle, which elevates the upper eyelid, is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III). Its proper functioning is essential for normal eyelid elevation.

 

Option D. Superior Rectus: Like the inferior rectus and levator palpebrae superioris, the superior rectus muscle is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III). This muscle is responsible for elevating the eyeball (looking up).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV), while the inferior rectus, levator palpebrae superioris, and superior rectus muscles are all innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III).

 

Ref: pg 359/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with horizontal double vision and limited abduction of the right eye, indicating the weakness of Lateral Rectus muscle of the right eye. Which cranial nerve supplies the involved muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abducens nerve

 

Option B:

 

LR6: The Lateral Rectus muscle is supplied by Abducens Nerve (CN 6).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abducens nerve supplies the lateral rectus, responsible for abduction of the eyeball.

 

Ref: pg 358/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Anterior cranial fossa
Middle cranial fossa
Posterior cranial fossa

questions.text: The optic nerve leaves the eye by piercing the sclera at lamina cribrosa, traverses the optic canal and enters the intracranial cavity. The optic canal connects the orbit to the which part of the cranium?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle cranial fossa

 

Option B:

 

  • The optic canal connects orbit to middle cranial fossa.
  • Contents of the optic canal:
  1. Optic nerve
  2. Ophthalmic artery

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior Cranial Fossa: This is the front part of the floor of the cranial cavity, housing the frontal lobes of the brain. However, the optic canal does not open into the anterior cranial fossa.

 

Option C. Posterior Cranial Fossa: This is the back part of the cranial cavity, containing the cerebellum, brainstem, and related structures. The optic canal does not connect to the posterior cranial fossa.

 

Option D. Maxillary Sinus: This is one of the paranasal sinuses, located in the maxillary bone. It is not connected to the orbit via the optic canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The optic canal connects the orbit to the middle cranial fossa, allowing the optic nerve and ophthalmic artery to pass from the orbit to the brain.

 

Ref: pg 580/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The highlighted muscle is innervated by which nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

 

Option B:

 

The highlighted muscle is Orbicularis oculi which is supplied by Facial nerve (CN VII).

 

ORIGIN: Medial palpebral ligament.

 

INSERTION: Muscle fibres sweep superiorly & inferiorly covering the orbital margins and meet at lateral palpebral raphe.

 

ACTION: Closure of the eye lids.

 

 

The remaining nerves and the muscles they supply:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (Cranial Nerve III): This nerve primarily controls most of the eye's movements and the constriction of the pupil. However, it does not innervate the orbicularis oculi muscle.

 

Option C. Abducent Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): This nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (outward). It does not innervate the orbicularis oculi.

 

Option D. Trigeminal Nerve (Cranial Nerve V): The trigeminal nerve is the main sensory nerve of the face and also provides motor fibers to the muscles of mastication. It does not provide innervation to the orbicularis oculi muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The orbicularis oculi muscle, responsible for closing the eyelids, is innervated by the facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII), which is key to understanding facial muscle control and the implications of facial nerve pathologies.


Ref: pg 491/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Central retinal artery
Anterior cerebral artery
Internal carotid artery
Middle meningeal artery

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the cavernous sinus:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal carotid artery

 

Option C:

 

Cavernous sinus is a large venous sinus located in the Middle cranial fossa.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Central Retinal Artery: The Central Retinal Artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery and enters the eye along with the optic nerve, supplying blood to the inner retinal layers.

 

Option B. Anterior Cerebral Artery: The Anterior Cerebral Artery originates from the internal carotid artery and travels anteriorly and medially to supply the medial portion of the frontal lobes and the superior medial parietal lobes of the brain.

 

Option D. Middle Meningeal Artery: The Middle Meningeal Artery is a branch of the maxillary artery (itself a branch of the external carotid artery) and enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum to supply the dura mater and the calvaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal carotid artery lies within the cavity of the cavernous sinus.

 

Ref: pg 519/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The marked muscle is innervated by?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CN 3

 

Option B:

 

  • The marked muscle is Levator palpebrae superioris. It is supplied by CN 3, Oculomotor nerve.
  • ORIGIN: Orbital apex
  • INSERTION: 
    1. Skin of eye lid
    2. Tarsal plate
    3. Conjunctival fornix

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CN 2 – It is the optic nerve a purely sensory nerve.

 

Option C. CN 4 – The supratrochlear nerve supplies the Superior Oblique Muscle.

 

Option D. CN 6 – The Abducens nerve supplies the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The muscle marked in the diagram is the superior rectus muscle, supplied by the CN 3.

 

Ref: pg 363/ EYE LIDS/ Comprehensive ophthalmology/ AK KHURANA/ 6th edition

questions.text: At what stage of gestation does the development of the eyeball begin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Day 22

 

The development of the eyeball begins on Day 22 of gestation when the embryo has 8 pair of somites and is 2mm in length.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Day 1: This marks the beginning of gestation when fertilization typically occurs. At this stage, the zygote (fertilized egg) is just beginning to undergo cell division. There is no specific organ development occurring yet, including the development of the eyeball.

 

Option B. Day 30: By this time, major developmental processes are underway, but this is past the initial formation of the eye structures. The eye begins to develop earlier than day 30.

 

Option D. Day 7: At this stage, the embryo is undergoing implantation in the uterine wall. There is no specific organ development occurring at this early stage, including the eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The development of the eyeball begins around Day 22 of gestation with the formation of the optic grooves or sulci, leading to the development of optic vesicles.

 

Ref: pg 8/ Comprehensive ophthalmology/ AK KHURANA/ 6th edition

questions.text: What is the weight of an adult eyeball?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7 gm

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The weight of an adult eyeball = 7 gm
  • The volume of an adult eyeball = 6.5 ml

 

Ref: pg 2/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: How much is the anteroposterior diameter of a normal adult eyeball?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 24mm

 

Explanation:
 

In an adult eyeball:

 

  • Anteroposterior diameter = 24mm
  • Horizontal diameter         = 23.5mm
  • Vertical diameter             = 23mm

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anteroposterior diameter of the eyeball is 24 mm.

 

Ref: pg 2/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: How much What is the circumference of an adult eyeball?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 75mm

 

Explanation:

 

The circumference of an adult eyeball = 75mm

questions.text: How much What is the volume of a normal adult eyeball?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6.5ml

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of an adult eyeball = 6.5 ml

 

 

Ref: pg 2/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which is the smallest diameter of an eyeball?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertical

 

Option B:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Horizontal: The horizontal diameter, also known as the equatorial diameter, typically measures about 24 mm. This is the widest diameter of the eye.

 

Option C. Anteroposterior: The anteroposterior diameter, or axial length, of the eye is the distance from the front (cornea) to the back (retina) of the eye. This measures approximately 22 to 24 mm in adults, making it similar or slightly less than the horizontal diameter.

 

Option D. Transverse: The term "transverse diameter" is less commonly used in reference to eye anatomy and generally considered synonymous with the horizontal diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The smallest diameter of an eyeball is the vertical diameter.

 

Ref: pg 2/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which structure of the eye marks the boundary for the anterior segment, including all the structures located in front of it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crystalline lens

 

Option B:

 

 

Anterior segment includes structures anterior to the crystalline lens. It is further divided into 2 chambers:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cornea: The cornea is the transparent anteriormost structure of the eyeball.

 

Option C. Iris: The iris is the pigmented part of the eye that controls the size of the pupil and amount of light that enters the eye. It is part of the anterior segment but does not define its boundary. The iris-pupillary plane divides the anterior segment of eye into anterior chamber and posterior chamber.

 

Option D. Vitreous: The vitreous is a clear gel that fills the space between the lens and the retina in the posterior segment of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The crystalline lens marks the boundary for the anterior segment of the eye, including all the structures located in front of it.

 

Ref: pg 5 / anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA
